description:
From the island of Bardos in the Aegean Sea comes a new threat to humanity in the form of Doctor Hell and his army of mechanical beasts. However, a new hero stands in his way: Mazinger Z, a giant robot built out of the indestructible metal chogokin and equipped with an arsenal of advanced weaponry. Piloting Mazinger Z is hotheaded teenager Kouji Kabuto, who strives to avenge the death of his grandfather and protect Japan from Doctor Hell's forces.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Primarily Male Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of male characters.

tags.name: Motorcycles
tags.description: Prominently features the use of motorcycles.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Lost Civilization
tags.description: Featuring a civilization with few ruins or records that exist in present day knowledge.

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

tags.name: Tsundere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who acts cold and hostile in order to mask warmer emotions.

name.native: シュトロハイム・ハインリッヒ

node.description:
Kiyoshi Nagai, better known by the pen name Gou Nagai, is a Japanese manga artist and a prolific author of science fiction, fantasy, horror and erotica. He made his professional debut in 1967 with Meakashi Polikichi, but is best known for creating popular 1970s manga and anime series such as [Cutie Honey](https://anilist.co/manga/86168/Cutey-Honey/), [Devilman](https://anilist.co/manga/31474/Devilman/) and [Mazinger Z](https://anilist.co/manga/38773/Mazinger-Z/). He is credited with creating the super robot genre and for designing the first mecha robots piloted by a user from within a cockpit with Mazinger Z, and for pioneering the magical girl genre with Cutie Honey, the post-apocalyptic genre with [Violence Jack](https://anilist.co/manga/31442/Violence-Jack/), and the ecchi genre with [Harenchi Gakuen](https://anilist.co/manga/42808/Harenchi-Gakuen/). 

In 2005, he became a Character Design professor at the Osaka University of Arts. He has been a member of the Tezuka Osamu Cultural Prize's nominating committee since 2009.
Nobutaka Nishizawa was a director, animator, and producer. He worked for [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/) from 1964 to 2000.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/伊藤道廣)

Founder and representative director of Sound Ring.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/奥山玲子)

Reiko Okuyama was notable for being one of the first female animators in the anime industry.

She spent much of her early life confined to bed due to a series of illnesses, and developed her interest in drawing during this time. After the end of World War II, she entered mission school. After graduation, she entered Tohoku University as per her father's wishes, but she eventually dropped out and left her home town to work in Tokyo.

In 1957, Okuyama applied for a position at Toei Animation, mistakenly believing that they were publishers of children's books. Her drawing skills were enough for her to be hired as an in-betweener. Her first work was on the landmark feature film, [Panda and the Magic Serpent](https://anilist.co/anime/4513/) in 1958. She was later promoted to 2nd key animator on [Magic Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/4948/), in spite of some sexual discrimination on the part of the studio heads. She was later promoted to key animator, and eventually to animation director.

She went freelance after briefly joining her husband [Youichi Kotabe](https://anilist.co/staff/115532/) at Nippon Animation. As a freelancer she worked as a printmaker, went on to illustrate several children's books and continued to teach animation at the Tokyo Designer Academy, which she had been doing since 1985.

Okuyama passed away from pneumonia on May 6, 2007.

Watanabe Chuumei  is a music composer and arranger. He graduated from Meiwa High School and went to University of Tokyo (Toudai) where he majored in Psychology.

He is a well known composer active for 50 years. His work included composition and arrangement for many popular artists, as well as composition work for film and tv drama. Another major source of his work were anime series.

While being mostly known under the name Watanabe Chuumei (ちゅうめい), his first name is actually read as Michiaki.

His son is the film and anime music composer [Watanabe Toshiyuki](https://anilist.co/staff/110725).

(Source: AniDB)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/ながきふさひろ)

Older brother of [Tatsuhiro Nagaki](https://anilist.co/staff/214258/).
